reviews.review_msg: This prof knows a lot about 18th century literature and is very clear about concepts. I will say that she is a very hard marker and that the final is very challenging. Not a GPA booster at all and should only be taken by students who are extremely interested in the subject.
Very nice. Knows his stuff. Be sure that your essay is flawless interms of format, gram. and MLA.

Betty is very knowledgeable and well respected, but she seems to have difficulty translating this into engaging lectures, and she is an incredibly nit-picky and particular marker. Also, she is not very understanding of students' extenuating circumstances as she refuses to budge on due dates (even in the middle of a pandemic).

SHE IS TOUGH. SHE WILL NOT HOLD YOUR HAND. BUT YOU WILL LEARN A LOT IF YOU PAY ATTENTION. She IS incredibly helpful and caring. Speak to anyone in the department, she's the most respected one (nationally/globally) out of all of them and she could go to any university she wanted to. Take her class if you actually care about the craft.
She's such a sweet professor (if you go talk to her in office hours).. but.. sigh.  Readings/quizzes aren't great. Welp, I hope I do well on the final.  Read the comment below.

She is way too hard on her students, expects too much, and there is too much reading. In addition to the long novels, there are long articles which, for the most part, have nothing to do with the focus of this course. She focuses a lot on city versus country. Will never take another course with her again!

an okay prof. seems nice and personable but her focus is all over the place and she is unorganized. the 5 novels were too much to read, and 3 of them seemed very repetetive. some articles we read were obscure and relating them to the material was a stretch. you won't get out of this class what you are required to put in, take with someone else.

Betty is an AMAZING prof. Yes, she is hard - I had to work my ass off for a decent mark. But, her comments and feedback are incredibly helpful - if you pay attention to what she's telling you, you WILL become a better writer. Lots of reading, yes. City/Country thing? I liked it - not so much a "hidden agenda" as a focal point/theme.

She seems to have a hidden agenda. Her focus for our class is more on the "city-country" theme than on the actual texts (possibly the focus of her own research?). Reading amount is too high even for a lit class. Very, very boring. Classmates complained of marking. On the first paper, the highest mark was an A-. And the class is very intelligent.

This guy really is awesome. Had an excellent course with him. He explains very clearly how you can do well in the course, and he does a great job of making his lectures engaging. He's got a sense of humor, which is refreshing from a prof. If you put effort into your papers and it's visible, he will reward you for that. Would definitely take again.

I took English 322 with Gavin this summer, and I must say that he is a very nice professor on all grounds. The only drawback is his strict marking scheme. He is particular about how you initiate quotes in the essay, and will surely mention that in the class :P But overall, very friendly and cute!
